29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
we have George Digweed bringing home the bacon

35.text:
in his quest for boar. The Banwen Miners hunt
are on song in the valleys the local curry

43.text:
house. We have more top gundog tips thanks
to our experts and their Skinners fed canines.

51.text:
First, it's a battle of speed and agility
– we're hunting hares with golden eagles.

58.text:
Although it may look like Roy has opened a
pet pampering parlour, this is all part of

72.text:
being a dedicated eagle falconer. Just as
their diet and weight needs constant monitoring

78.text:
so do all the other important bits – you
wouldn't take a racing car out without warming

83.text:
the tyres or an aeroplane up without checking
flaps and ailerons, would you, Ginger? Likewise,

89.text:
you don't take a golden eagle out after hares
without dry feathers. But this comes with

94.text:
a serious health warning: Teflon coated stuff
kills birds, be it a parrot or a peregrine.

101.text:
If your bird inhales the heated gas then that
can kill them. A lot of the parrot forums

106.text:
talk about it as well with people cooking
in their houses with Teflon pans. And again

111.text:
the fumes from those can kill the birds, so
if you are using something like that then

115.text:
obviously be incredibly careful and make sure
it hasn't got a PTFE or Teflon coating on

120.text:
From fluffing feathers to the beak bar for
a bit of a trim.

124.text:
In the wild they would be eating a lot more
hard bone material than we currently feed

128.text:
them when we are flying them. So they are
constantly wearing their beak down. So they

132.text:
also do what we call feeking where they rub
their beak on rocks and that trims them as

137.text:
well. When we are flying them a lot of the
time they are eating reasonably soft food

142.text:
so the beak can become overgrown quite quickly.
There is no discomfort. It is just like trimming

153.text:
Lincolnshire is well known for its hares and
Roy and his friends have been coming to this

156.text:
part of the England for years. There's a promise
of some serious action today and with four

162.text:
male goldies and one female, our chances are
good.

164.text:
A female golden eagle, a male golden eagle.
So you can see the female is comparatively

169.text:
larger. And that is pretty much all the way
through with most birds of prey that the females

174.text:
are normally about a third larger. They are
much more capable of taking fox and on the

179.text:
continent they obviously fly a lot of roe
deer as well with them.

185.text:
The guys line up. Roy choreographs the beating
line. It's going to be hard going today with

190.text:
the heavy Lincolnshire soil, but there are
definitely hares to be had here.

195.text:
Gary has the first flight. It's brown hares
one, eagles nil.

200.text:
Luckily it went down hill so he got a bit
of steam up and took it. Sat on it bold up

205.text:
and as it started to run it popped up out
of his feet and ran off. Which is hunting

214.text:
The next drive flushes more hares. Unfortunately,
Mark's youngster doesn't have the juice to

219.text: keep chasing this high speed quarry.

221.text:
It was a shame about Mark's young eagle there.
It was too much for it with the wind he has

226.text:
got. The wind has picked up a little bit and
expecting it to fly into that sort of heavy

230.text:
wind it just took the speed out of it and
the eagle knew that he didn't quite have the

232.text: power to catch up with the hare.

237.text:
The guys walk field after field. The hares
at this time of year are properly match fit

244.text: so are really testing the birds.

249.text:
The most exciting flights of the day are in
the afternoon. Roy spots a hare in its seat.

272.text: Let's watch that again in slow motion.

275.text:
Roy's male eagle, Baby, chases down the hare
which at the last moment turns to face his

280.text:
pursuer – Incredibly the hare judges to
the nano second when Baby is going to commit.

286.text:
He spins up into the air away from those razor
sharp talons and makes his escape.

291.text:
When you see the hares doing manoeuvres like
that you really do have to question whether

295.text:
that is an inherent behaviour that they know,
how to avoid an air borne predator or if they

302.text:
have run the gauntlet and avoided buzzards
when they were a lot younger being predated

307.text:
upon as leverets. Which ever way round they
really, really do demand a lot of respect

315.text:
Next up for a decent flight is Gary's bird.
The fur flies, but again the hare slips through

330.text:
There are more close calls and all the birds
get some hunting. It's really exciting stuff,

335.text:
but the hares have won today, and Roy finds
it tough to admit defeat.

339.text:
No, no ... don't ... great misses ... right
hang on ... oh you don't know how much this

349.text:
All in all we had a superb day. Some brilliant
sport. Some very, very close calls. How the

354.text:
birds didn't keep hold of some of those hares
I don't know. I think somebody must have come

358.text:
out last night and smothered them in grease
because they were definitely slipping out

362.text:
of the bird's feet on this occasion. So we
shall have to try harder next time.

366.text:
With hunting there's always tomorrow and,
after a misty start, the Lincolnshire countryside

371.text:
clears. Finally, the eagles find their targets.
Baby shows us how it's done.

377.text:
We spotted another hare in a seat and walked
it up and that one ran perfectly though it

383.text:
ran down the field and gave him a little bit
of an advantage and he made short work of

388.text:
that and cut into it. So again when you see
an experienced eagle fly they will go at it.

394.text:
Cut round to the side and then come back into
it. So it just puts the hare off.

400.text:
On this second flight the experience of a
bird with seven seasons under its wings is

405.text:
clear. Instead of crashing into the hedge
after the hare, Baby bides his time, waiting

410.text:
for the hare to appear the other side. His
patience pays off with a majestic 400 yard

420.text:
Eagle falconers are a dedicated bunch, putting
in hours of work and preparation for a flight

425.text:
that could last just a few seconds. It's a
drug – and Roy can't give it up.

431.text:
You find the best flights when it is a 50,
50 chance whether the quarry escapes or whether

438.text:
the bird does well and I think that is what
drives us and what keeps us going. Just wanting

445.text:
to be part of the hunt, wanting to see it
and having nature in its rawest form played

452.text:
And Nature has given both the predator and
prey the best tools for the job.

460.text:
Well we have made lots of films about both
eagles and falconry and of course with Roy

464.text:
Lupton. They should be appearing on the screen
just there. You can click on that if you are

469.text:
watching this on Youtube and go straight through
to watch some of them.

471.text:
Now from the high octane world of falcons
to the more sedentary Fieldsports Channel

488.text:
The Angling Trust has brought out a video
spelling out the problems of cormorants on

494.text:
The Angling trust admits that the predators
are part of the natural ecosystem, however,

499.text:
there are many places where ecosystems are
not natural or where fish populations are

504.text:
suffering from other impacts. The trust adds
that Anglers who try to apply for licences

508.text:
to shoot cormorants and goosanders find the
process bureaucratic. One of its members had

513.text:
85 cormorants sitting on a pylon overlooking
his fishery, and was given a licence to shoot

520.text:
The Thoresby Country Fair in Nottinghamshire
on 2nd and 3rd March sees a big change this

526.text:
year. It's bigger and better with three main
show arenas.

531.text:
Among attractions are dare devil stunts, fast
and scurry racing, dog displays and falconry.

536.text:
There are also more traditional countryside
attractions such as long netting, ferret racing

540.text:
and gundog displays. There is a falconry village
and arena, and an owl show. It is all taking

546.text:
place at the Thoresby Park with the backdrop
of the Thoresby Hall Hotel, near Ollerton,

556.text:
An RSPCA private prosecution brought against
a Cheshire hunt supporter, his partner and

562.text:
their nineteen year old daughter has collapsed
on the first morning of a scheduled three

565.text:
day trial at Crewe Magistrates'Court. The
family had been accused of interference with

570.text:
a badger sett when Mr Watson was assisting
the Cheshire Hunt . RSPCA prosecutors admitted,

576.text:
despite knowing all the facts of the case
for more than a year, that there was no realistic

580.text:
prospect of conviction on the evidence and
the case was dismissed, with the taxpayer

590.text:
The American star of the film Walk The Line,
Joaquin Phoenix, has made a film for the animal

594.text:
rights group PETA to persuade you to go vegan.
In it, he highlights the fact that fish caught

601.text:
commercially are not knocked on the head but
drowned in the air. He does this by reenacting

607.text:
what it's like to be a fish out of water.
You provide the punch line. For the rest of

611.text: the film, click on the link on the screen.

615.text:
The Scottish Government plans to massacre
700 mainly pregnant deer on a Scottish estate

622.text:
Scottish Natural Heritage says that the area
around Caenlochan in Angus had not met a 10

626.text:
year old government imposed target of 19 animals
per square kilometre, so it would be moving

631.text:
its own shooters into the area to carry out
the cull, even though most of the red hinds

635.text:
are in calf. The Scottish Gamekeepers Association
has condemned the move, calling it ' a bloodbath'.

642.text:
And finally, there are two remarkable stories
of deer with their antlers locked this week.

647.text:
Both come from the USA and both are whitetail
bucks.

650.text:
In this one, one of the two deer had died.
Illinois Conservation Police Officer Steven

654.text:
Beltran was dispatched to break them free
with a pruning saw on a long pole.

659.text:
The second films is more remarkable, and the
clearest evidence we have yet seen that British

664.text:
police should be armed. The two deer have
locked antlers as before. The officer uses

669.text:
his handgun to shoot once, twice, three, he
moves position, four then five times. Are

680.text:
the deer dead? They are not. They are separated.
It might not be good deer management to have

685.text:
two partially de-antlered bucks running around
but you have to admire the shooting.

691.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

703.text:
Thank you David. Now George Digweed 20 times
world champion shooter has been having a problem

709.text:
with wild boar. You would think the odds were
loaded against the boar. Let's find out.

715.text:
We are in Sussex where George Digweed's boar
problem started last autumn but the shooting

723.text:
season put a stop to any control measures.
He has tried driving them in the daytime,

728.text:
lamping them at night time and he still hasn't
been able to enjoy that Asterix and Obelix

735.text:
Tonight he's feeling confident. The local
gamekeeper has been putting some feed down

739.text:
and the boar have locked on to it. George
hopes he will get a chance to pull the trigger

745.text:
We're going to try and maximise our chances
with some infra red filming. It is nowhere

751.text:
near the class of the night vision we've used
recently but we're hoping it'll give us an

757.text:
What isn't giving an edge is the electric
polaris. Even though it's in stealth mode

762.text:
the water logged fields give us away and our
first boar doesn't stay around long enough

766.text:
for us. However, a second is just around the
corner and George is quick to get on to it.

772.text:
The boar drops. We hold back and wait – but
this pig isn't going anywhere.

777.text:
It is not something I like doing. But I would
rather do it than have the cowboys riding

784.text:
around shooting them all up the arse. I will
always shoot them in the head or just behind

790.text:
the ear, top of the neck somewhere there and
then it guarantees an immediate kill where

799.text:
it is on the spot. Heart shots at this time
of the night. Everybody knows that heart shots

804.text:
they tend to run and in the dark, you can't
you could take a heart shot during the day

811.text:
because you can track it and find it. But
at this time of night you have got no method

816.text:
of tracking it so I will shoot it somewhere
where it is instantaneous.

819.text:
Our boar is a young male which is some consolation
to the world champion. Incredibly boar don't

825.text: have a closed season in the UK.

827.text:
From the end of this month I wouldn't want
to be shooting sows. It is an excellent size

836.text:
for the table. It will eat well, make some
good sausages as well. All in all it is an

850.text:
This boar fell under an oak tree where much
of the damage to the pasture had been concentrated.

855.text:
There is no doubt about it they have got to
be controlled. If you look behind you, you

858.text:
will see the damage that they are doing and
here look, just in here. That is not ... if

862.text:
I put just a knife in there you can see how
deep they are going down. There are a lot

869.text:
of acorn shucks and that sort of thing. Probably
looking for acorns from last year. You can

878.text:
see how deep that is. So they are doing a
lot of damage. I look to see them about and

887.text:
I like to think myself as a conservationist,
but at the end of the day everything needs

892.text:
to be controlled and we have got to shoot
one or two. So we roll one or two over and

899.text:
you come out and film it being done properly
and hopefully people will see it like that.

905.text:
So success at last. George feels he's done
his job on behalf of the landowner, whilst

911.text:
ensuring that it was done to the best of his
ability. And there are some delicious sausages

918.text:
Well we made lots of films about British wild
boar and you should be able to see some of

them playing on that screen up there. Click

928.text:
from wild boar to the wild welsh hillside.
Nicky Sadler has been off with the Banwen

937.text:
Hi I am Nicky Sadler and I am out in south
Wales out hunting with the Banwen Miners Hunt

945.text:
at one of their best meets and guess where
we are, how cool is this, at a curry house.

960.text:
It is the Banwen Miners 50th anniversary season.
This used to be one of the best loved hunting

967.text:
pubs in the area. Eve though there's been
a bit of a culture change, the new Indian

971.text:
owners of this restaurant welcome the hunt,
just like the Glamorgan Arms used to.

975.text:
The master that I remember the most of would
be William Hancock. Big Billy, yeah a hunter

982.text:
through and through. If you cut him half way
through I think he would have Banwen Miners

986.text:
written like a stick of rock going through
his body. There is actually a film available,

990.text:
I have got a copy at home and it was filmed
on the day of the opening meet and they actually

996.text:
film the miners coming up from the pit, showering,
putting their hunting clothes on and coming

1002.text:
out and the guy on the film says to some of
the boys in the film, do they take the micky

1014.text:
out of you. Oh yes they call us the lord and
this that and the other and it was just so

1017.text:
out of character to see these red coats appearing
all on welsh cobs and just going across and

1023.text:
hunting the coal tops, the slag heaps and
the coal mines.

1027.text: Was it very much a working mans hunt.

1029.text:
Oh yes, definitely, it always has been and
Billy I think he fought for that, to keep

1035.text:
Earlier this morning, I met master/huntsman
Peter Astle at the Banwen's smart, newly-refurbished

1041.text:
We never had the puppy show at the kennels
before, before two years ago. We managed to

1047.text:
have the puppy show at the kennels which is
very nice, which I think is part of the kennels.

1052.text:
Part of hunting really and it is nice to have
hounds showing in their own area really.

1060.text: To the kennels. That is right.

1062.text:
After breakfast at a glamorous local establishment,
we set off for the meet.

1066.text: This is a hunt that really welcomes youngsters.

1068.text:
I was with a lady last week who has the youngest
member of the hunt, her daughter is about

1074.text:
six or seven years old and she said to me
whatever is on if there is show jumping or

1080.text:
if there is hunting on that day, she asks
the child what she wants to do she'll say

1084.text:
She is great to see. Sometimes she is on a
lead rein, sometimes she is not, when they

1090.text:
are galloping along she'll tack in next to
somebody else and I just think it is the next

1096.text:
generation and the hunts which don't encourage
the kids they will be the ones that struggle

1101.text:
We follow a trail up Mynydd y Graig, which
is Welsh for mountain. Peter and his partner

1107.text:
built some hunt jumps for the mounted field
to pop. Even the hounds follow the trail over

1113.text:
The hunt has a strong sense of responsibility
to local farmers and provides both a lambing

1118.text:
call-out service, shooting foxes to order
and a free stock collection service.

1122.text:
Since I have been here I have tried to do
as much as I can for the farmers. I was farming

1126.text:
born and bred. From the ... to the head. I
try and do as much as I can for the farmers

1135.text:
as in fallen stock wise. Years ago when I
was here before we used to pick up anything

1141.text:
up to 22 calves a day. The dairy herds have
gone out of the country now. We haven't got

1144.text:
the dairy herds. We had 11 or 12 dairy herds
in the country then. We haven't got the dairy

1149.text:
herds the same, so it is more of a struggle
in that way. Sometimes we run a bit tight

1155.text:
for flesh and I have to go into Carmarthen
country and get flesh. But generally I like

1157.text:
to do as much as we can. We do have Goddards
and we do have others now picking up in our

1164.text:
country. But we do all need to work together
at the end of the day and because I am the

1168.text:
local person I think it is right that I am
doing our picking up in our area really. And

1174.text:
that is what I have tried to help the farmers
with as much as I can.

1177.text:
The Banwen miners is a fun-loving, tight-knit
community with many loyal followers. You will

1182.text:
find several generations of the same family
following the hunt here. They also welcome

1187.text: new faces, as long as they love hunting.

1190.text:
My wife, she is hunting. We have a young kid
and I have been trained for dressage and for

1195.text:
hunting have a nice big horse there. I come
every week with three horses on this hunt.

1201.text:
I also bring other people with me. It is not
far for me. If you want to hunt. If you want

1206.text:
to hunt I will come. If you want nice people
I will come.

1209.text: A sales man for the Banwen.

1212.text:
It is nice because as I said we need more
people on the hunt.

1216.text:
The hunt has give the field a fabulous gallop
over beautiful Welsh hills – and even provided

1221.text: welcome exercise for a handful of anties.

1223.text:
We have had a lovely day out with the Banwen
Miners today. Met some really lovely people

1227.text:
and had a very warm welsh welcome. If you
would like to find out more information about

1232.text:
the Banwen, please visit their website www.banwenminershunt.co.uk
and for further information about the Countryside

1241.text:
Alliance and the campaign for hunting visit

training tips with Skinners Petfoods maker

Picking up game is a knack for any dog, especially

1274.text:
day. Top gundog trainer Ricky Moloney shows
how to help them along and pick up really

1280.text:
I am going to send the dog up for the hare
just up the field. I want to give him as much

1285.text:
experience carrying these bigger objects and
managing them well. That is the idea.

1293.text:
How do you get a dog to pick up game if it
is not used to it. Just experience?

1307.text:
I think it is experience. I think you can
create problems. If I look at the way Den

1314.text:
handles hers at the moment it is very lacking
in confidence, but the last thing I want to

1319.text:
do is apply any pressure to him. So when he
goes and picks it up and drops it I don't

1323.text:
say good boy as then he is getting rewarded
for dropping the hare. I don't want to growl

1330.text:
at him or grumble at him because that type
of dog will have trouble with picking the

1334.text:
hare. He might just run back to me, so what
I have got to do is I have actually got to

1339.text:
let him, as painful as it might be for me
watching, I have actually got to let him learn

1345.text:
how to handle a hare. There is no short cut
I have just got to keep him picking, picking,

like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1592.text:
We are back next week. If you have enjoyed
this programme please hit the subscribe button

1596.text:
which is somewhere on the outside of the screen

you can click to like us on Face Book follow
